movie.title: Casablanca
movie.basedOn: Everybody Comes to Rickâ€™s (stage play); written by Murray Burnett and Joan Alison

scene.setting: EXT. RICK'S CAFE - NIGHT Ilsa and Laszlo leave the cafe.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: A very puzzling fellow, this Rick. What sort is he?

scene.dir: Ilsa doesn't look at him.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Oh, I really can't say, though I saw him quite often in Paris.

scene.dir: They join Renault at the curb.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Tomorrow at ten at the Prefect's office.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: We'll be there.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Goodnight.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Goodnight.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Goodnight.

scene.dir: They get into a waiting cab, leaving Renault on the curb, smoking and looking bemused. The neon sign goes off and the doorway is now illuminated by the revolving beacon from the airport.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - MAIN ROOM - NIGHT The customers have all gone. The house lights are out. Rick sits alone at a table. There is a glass of bourbon on the table directly in front of him, and another empty glass on the table before an empty chair. Near at hand is a bottle. He fills his glass and drinks it quickly. Rick just sits. His face is entirely expressionless. The beacon light from the airport sweeps around the room creating a mood of unreality. Sam comes in and stands hesitantly beside Rick.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: Boss.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: Boss!

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Yeah?

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: Boss, ain't you going to bed?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Not right now.

scene.dir: Sam now realizes Rick is in a very grim mood.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: lightly Ain't you planning on going to bed in the near future?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: No.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: You ever going to bed?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: No.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: Well, I ain't sleepy either.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Good. Then have a drink.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: No. Not me, boss.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Then don't have a drink.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: Boss, let's get out of here.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: emphatically No, sir. I'm waiting for a lady.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: earnestly Please, boss, let's go. Ain't nothing but trouble for you here.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: She's coming back. I know she's coming back.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: We'll take the car and drive all night. We'll get drunk. We'll go fishing and stay away until she's gone.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Shut up and go home, will you?

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: stubbornly No, sir. I'm staying right here.

scene.dir: Sam sits down at the piano and starts to play softly, improvising.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: They grab Ugarte and she walks in. Well, that's the way it goes. One in, one out. Sam?

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: Yeah, boss?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Sam, if it's December 1941 in Casablanca, what time is it in New York?

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: Uh, my watch stopped.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I bet they're asleep in New York. I'll bet they're asleep all over America.

scene.dir: Suddenly he pounds the table and buries his head in his arms. Then he raises his head, trying to regain control.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Of all the gin joints in all the towns in all the world, she walks into mine.

scene.dir: He holds his head in his hands.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: What's that you're playing?

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: Just a little something of my own.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Well, stop it. You know what I want to hear.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: No, I don't.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: You played it for her and you can play it for me.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: Well, I don't think I can remember it.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: If she can stand it, I can. Play it!

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: Yes, boss.

scene.dir: Sam starts to play "As Time Goes By." Rick just stares ahead as orchestra MUSIC slowly joins Sam's playing.

body.dir: DISSOLVE TO: MONTAGE - PARIS IN THE SPRING A) The Arc de Triomphe from a distance. B) Rick drives a small, open car slowly along the boulevard. He puts his arm around Ilsa. The background scenery changes to a country road as she snuggles close to him and puts her head on his shoulder. C) An excursion boat on the Seine. Rick and Ilsa stand at the rail of the boat. They seem to be transported by each other as Ilsa laughs.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S PARIS APARTMENT - DAY Ilsa fixes flowers at the window while Rick opens champagne. She walks over and joins him.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Who are you really? And what were you before? What did you do and what did you think? Huh?

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: We said "no questions."

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Here's looking at you, kid.

scene.dir: They drink.

scene.setting: INT. PARIS CAFE - NIGHT Inside a swank Paris cafe, Rick and Ilsa dance. They appear to be very much in love as the MUSIC plays.
INT. ILSA'S PARIS APARTMENT - DAY Ilsa flips a coin, then tosses it over to Rick.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: A franc for your thoughts.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: In America they'd bring only a penny. I guess that's about all they're worth.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: I'm willing to be overcharged. Tell me.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: And I was wondering.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Yes?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Why I'm so lucky. Why I should find you waiting for me to come along.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Why there is no other man in my life?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Uh huh.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: That's easy. There was. He's dead.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I'm sorry for asking. I forgot we said "no questions."

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Well, only one answer can take care of all our questions.

scene.dir: They kiss passionately.

body.dir: CUT TO: MONTAGE - NEWSREEL FOOTAGE OF THE GERMAN OCCUPATION OF FRANCE. A) The rubble of a burned-out, demolished building. A sign with an arrow points to Paris. B) German troops crossing a river. C) Tanks rolling down the road toward Paris. D) German war planes overhead.

scene.setting: EXT. PARIS CAFE - DAY A man sells newspapers to people crowded around him. There is much excitement. Rick and Ilsa sit at a table. They buy a newspaper and begin to read it. Nearby, a group of frightened French people cluster around a loudspeaker on a wagon. A harsh voice barks out the tragic news of the Nazi push toward Paris.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Nothing can stop them now. Wednesday, Thursday at the latest, they'll be in Paris.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: frightened Richard, they'll find out your record. It won't be safe for you here.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I'm on their blacklist already, their roll of honor.

scene.setting: INT. LA BELLE AURORE - AFTERNOON A small cafe in the Montmartre. A shadow on the floor reflects the cafe sign "La Belle Aurore." Rick, at the bar, gets glasses and a bottle of champagne. He walks over to Ilsa and Sam at the piano. Sam plays "As Time Goes By." Ilsa seems unnerved. There is evidently something on her mind. Rick pours the champagne. His manner is wry, but not the bitter wryness we have seen in Casablanca.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Henri wants us to finish this bottle and then three more. He says he'll water his garden with champagne before he'll let the Germans drink any of it.

scene.dir: Sam looks at his glass.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: This sort of takes the sting out of being occupied, doesn't it, Mr. Richard?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: You said it! to Ilsa Here's looking at you, kid.

scene.setting: Suddenly a loudspeaker BLARES out something in German.
scene.dir: Rick and Ilsa look at each other, then hurry to the window.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: My German's a little rusty.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: It's the Gestapo. They say they expect to be in Paris tomorrow. They are telling us how to act when they come marching in.

scene.dir: She smiles faintly.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: With the whole world crumbling, we pick this time to fall in love.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Yeah. It's pretty bad timing. Where were you, say, ten years ago?

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Ten years ago? Let's see-- pause as she thinks a bit --Yes. I was having a brace put on my teeth. Where were you?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Looking for a job.

scene.dir: Ilsa looks at him tenderly. Rick takes her in his arms, and kisses her hungrily. While they are locked in an embrace they hear the dull BOOM of cannons.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: frightened Was that cannon fire, or is it my heart pounding?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: grimly Ah, that's the new German 77. And judging by the sound, only about thirty-five miles away.

scene.setting: Another BOOM from the cannons.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: And getting closer every minute. Here. Drink up. We'll never finish the other three.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: The Germans'll be here pretty soon now, and they'll come looking for you. And don't forget there's a price on your head.

scene.dir: Ilsa reacts to this worriedly.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I left a note in my apartment. They'll know where to find me.

scene.dir: Ilsa looks at Rick.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Strange. I know so very little about you.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I know very little about you, just the fact that you had your teeth straightened.

scene.dir: He chuckles.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: But be serious, darling. You are in danger and you must leave Paris.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: No, no, no, no. We must leave.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: seriously Yes, of course, we --

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: -- The train for Marseilles leaves at five o'clock. I'll pick you up at your hotel at four-thirty.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: quickly No, no. Not at my hotel. I, uh, I have things to do in the city before I leave. I'll meet you at the station, huh?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: All right. At a quarter to five. a thought strikes him Say, why don't we get married in Marseilles?

scene.dir: Rick chuckles again.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: evasively That's too far ahead to plan.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Yes, I guess it is a little too far ahead. Well, let's see. What about the engineer? Why can't he marry us on the train?

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Oh, darling!

scene.dir: Suddenly Ilsa turns away and starts to cry.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Well, why not? The captain on a ship can. It doesn't seem fair that-- Hey, hey, what's wrong, kid?

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: I love you so much, and I hate this war so much. Oh, it's a crazy world. Anything can happen. If you shouldn't get away, I mean, if, if something should keep us apart, wherever they put you and wherever I'll be, I want you to know--

scene.dir: She can't go on. She lifts her face to his. He kisses her gently.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Kiss me. Kiss me as if it were the last time.

scene.dir: He looks into her eyes, then he does kiss her as though it were going to be the last time. Her hand falls to the table and knocks over a glass.

scene.setting: INT. GARE DE LYON - NIGHT It's raining very hard at the train station. There is a hectic, fevered excitement, evident in the faces of the people that pass by. This is the last train from Paris. Rick appears in the crowd. He stops and puts his suitcase down and glances at his watch. A conductor calls out "All aboard, last train leaving in three minutes." Rain pours over his head and shoulders, but he doesn't seem to notice. He nervously checks his watch again. Suddenly Sam appears.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Where is she? Have you seen her?

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: No, Mr. Richard. I can't find her. She checked out of the hotel. But this note came just after you left.

scene.dir: Sam pulls an envelope from his pocket. Rick grabs it, opens it, and stares down at the letter.
INSERT LETTER Richard, I cannot go with you or ever see you again. You must not ask why. Just believe that I love you. Go, my darling, and God bless you. Ilsa
scene.setting: Raindrops pour down the letter, smudging the writing.
scene.dir: BACK TO SCENE
scene.setting: A whistle BLOWS.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: frantically That's the last call, Mr. Richard, do you hear me? Come on, Mr. Richard. Let's get out of here. Come on, Mr. Richard, come on.

scene.dir: Sam pulls a stunned, reluctant Rick to the train. The train starts to move just as he boards. From the steps he looks off into the distance, then crumbles the letter and tosses it away as the steam from the engine clouds over him.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - MAIN ROOM - NIGHT Close-up of a glass on the table in the cafe. Rick's hand reaches for it and knocks it over. We now see Rick's face and he's very drunk. Sam walks over to the table to pick up the glass and a fallen chair. Just then the door opens and it's Ilsa. Rick stares at the doorway. Ilsa lingers a moment, then comes over to the table.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Rick, I have to talk to you.

scene.dir: Her manner is a little uncertain, a little tentative, but with a quiet determination beneath it.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Oh. I saved my first drink to have with you. Here.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: No. No, Rick. Not tonight.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Especially tonight.

scene.dir: She sits down in the chair before the empty glass. Her eyes are searching his face, but there is no expression on it except a cold and impassive one. Rick reaches for the bottle, and pours himself another drink.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Please.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Why did you have to come to Casablanca? There are other places.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: I wouldn't have come if I had known that you were here. Believe me, Rick, it's true. I didn't know.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: It's funny about your voice, how it hasn't changed. I can still hear it. "Richard dear, I'll go with you any place. We'll get on a train together and never stop."

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Please don't. Don't, Rick. I can understand how you feel.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Huh! You understand how I feel. How long was it we had, honey?

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: I didn't count the days.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Well, I did. Every one of them. Mostly I remember the last one. A wow finish. A guy standing on a station platform in the rain with a comical look on his face, because his insides had been kicked out.

scene.dir: He takes a drink.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Can I tell you a story, Rick?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Has it got a wow finish?

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: I don't know the finish yet.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Well, go on, tell it. Maybe one will come to you as you go along.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: It's about a girl who had just come to Paris from her home in Oslo. At the house of some friends she met a man about whom she'd heard her whole life, a very great and courageous man. He opened up for her a whole beautiful world full of knowledge and thoughts and ideals. Everything she knew or ever became was because of him. And she looked up to him and worshipped him with a feeling she supposed was love.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Yes, that's very pretty. I heard a story once. As a matter of fact, I've heard a lot of stories in my time. They went along with the sound of a tinny piano playing in the parlor downstairs, "Mister, I met a man once when I was a kid," it'd always begin. Huh. I guess neither one of our stories was very funny. Tell me, who was it you left me for? Was it Laszlo, or were there others in between? Or aren't you the kind that tells?

scene.dir: Ilsa gets up and leaves. Rick's head slumps over the table.

scene.setting: INT. RENAULT'S OFFICE - MORNING A sign on the door reads: Captain Renault, Prefect de Police. Strasser sits while Renault attends to some paperwork.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: I strongly suspect that Ugarte left the letters of transit with Mr. Blaine. I would suggest you search the cafe immediately and thoroughly.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: If Rick has the letters, he's much too smart to let you find them there.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: You give him credit for too much cleverness. My impression was that he's just another blundering American.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: But we mustn't underestimate American blundering. I was with them when they "blundered" into Berlin in 1918.

scene.dir: Strasser looks at him.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: As to Laszlo, we want him watched twenty-four hours a day.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: reassuringly It may interest you to know that at this very moment he is on his way here.

scene.setting: INT. PREFECTURE LOBBY - MORNING Laszlo and Ilsa make their way through the jam in the lobby of the Prefecture. Jan and Annina talk to an officer.

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.diag: to Jan and Annina There's nothing we can do.

scene.setting: INT. RENAULT'S OFFICE - MORNING Laszlo and Ilsa enter Renault's office. Renault bows to them both.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: I am delighted to see you both. Did you have a good night's rest?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: I slept very well.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: That's strange. Nobody is supposed to sleep well in Casablanca.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: coldly May we proceed with the business?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: With pleasure. Won't you sit down?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Thank you.

scene.dir: They take their seats.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: now as cold as Laszlo Very well, Herr Laszlo, we will not mince words. You are an escaped prisoner of the Reich. So far you have been fortunate enough in eluding us. You have reached Casablanca. It is my duty to see that you stay in Casablanca.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Whether or not you succeed is, of course, problematical.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Not at all. Captain Renault's signature is necessary on every exit visa. turns to Renault Captain, would you think it is possible that Herr Laszlo will receive a visa?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: I am afraid not. My regrets, Monsieur.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Well, perhaps I shall like it in Casablanca.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: And Mademoiselle?

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: You needn't be concerned about me.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Is that all you wish to tell us?

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Don't be in such a hurry. You have all the time in the world. You may be in Casablanca indefinitely-- or you may leave for Lisbon tomorrow, on one condition.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: And that is?

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: You know the leaders of the underground movement in Paris, in Prague, in Brussels, in Amsterdam, in Oslo, in Belgrade, in Athens.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Even in Berlin.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Yes, even in Berlin. If you will furnish me with their names and their exact whereabouts, you will have your visa in the morning.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: And the honor of having served the Third Reich.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: I was in a German concentration camp for a year. That's honor enough for a lifetime.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: You will give us the names?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: If I didn't give them to you in a concentration camp where you had more "persuasive methods" at your disposal, I certainly won't give them to you now.

scene.dir: The passionate conviction in his voice now reveals the crusader.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: And what if you track down these men and kill them? What if you murdered all of us? From every corner of Europe, hundreds, thousands, would rise to take our places. Even Nazis can't kill that fast.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Herr Laszlo, you have a reputation for eloquence which I can now understand. But in one respect you are mistaken. You said the enemies of the Reich could all be replaced, but there is one exception. No one could take your place in the event anything unfortunate should occur to you while you were trying to escape.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: You won't dare to interfere with me here. This is still unoccupied France. Any violation of neutrality would reflect on Captain Renault.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Monsieur, insofar as it is in my power --

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: -- Thank you.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: By the way, Monsieur, last night you evinced an interest in Signor Ugarte.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Yes.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: I believe you have a message for him?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Nothing important, but may I speak to him now?

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: You would find the conversation a trifle one-sided. Signor Ugarte is dead.

scene.dir: Close-ups of Ilsa, then Laszlo, reveal their disappointment. Strasser observes their reaction.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: softly Oh. Renault holds a report.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: I am making out the report now. We haven't quite decided whether he committed suicide or died trying to escape.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Are you quite finished with us?

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: For the time being.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Good day.

scene.dir: Renault rings a buzzer and the door is opened for them. As Ilsa and Laszlo leave, an OFFICER comes in.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Undoubtedly their next step will be to the black market.

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.diag: Excuse me, Captain. Another visa problem has come up.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Show her in.

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.diag: Yes, sir.

scene.dir: Renault looks at himself in the mirror and straightens his tie.

scene.setting: EXT. BLACK MARKET - DAY The black market is a cluttered Arab street of bazaars, shops and stalls. All kinds and races of people mill about the merchandise which native dealers have on outdoor display. Both men and women are dressed in tropical clothes. The canopies over the stalls give them some protection from the scorching sun. On the surface the atmosphere is merely languid, but underneath lies the sinister workings of illicit trade. A FRENCHMAN and a NATIVE huddle together and talk in low tones.

sp.speaker: NATIVE
sp.diag: I'm sorry, Monsieur, we would have to handle the police. This is a job for Signor Ferrari.

sp.speaker: FRENCHMAN
sp.diag: Ferrari?

sp.speaker: NATIVE
sp.diag: It can be most helpful to know Signor Ferrari. He pretty near has a monopoly on the black market here. You will find him over there at the Blue Parrot.

sp.speaker: FRENCHMAN
sp.diag: Thanks.

scene.setting: EXT. THE BLUE PARROT - DAY Outside the cafe, a blue parrot sits on a perch.

INT. THE BLUE PARROT - DAY The cafe is much less pretentious than Rick's, but well populated. Rick enters and walks through the cafe toward Ferrari's office just as Ferrari emerges with Jan and Annina, who look very disappointed.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: There, don't be too downhearted. Perhaps you can come to terms with Captain Renault.

sp.speaker: JAN
sp.diag: Thank you very much, Signor.

scene.dir: Jan leads Annina away.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Hello, Ferrari.

scene.dir: Signor Ferrari turns around. He's pleased to see Rick.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: Ah, good morning, Rick.

scene.dir: They shake hands.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I see the bus is in. I'll take my shipment with me.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: No hurry. I'll have it sent over. Have a drink with me.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I never drink in the morning. And every time you send my shipment over, it's always just a little bit short.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: chuckling Carrying charges, my boy, carrying charges. Here, sit down. There's something I want to talk over with you, anyhow.

scene.dir: He hails a waiter.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: The bourbon. to Rick, sighing deeply The news about Ugarte upset me very much.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: You're a fat hypocrite. You don't feel any sorrier for Ugarte than I do.

scene.dir: He eyes Rick closely.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: Of course not. What upsets me is the fact that Ugarte is dead and no one knows where those letters of transit are.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Practically no one.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: If I could lay my hands on those letters, I could make a fortune.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: So could I. And I'm a poor businessman.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: I have a proposition for whoever has those letters. I will handle the entire transaction, get rid of the letters, take all the risk, for a small percentage.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: And the carrying charges?

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: Naturally there will be a few incidental expenses. That is the proposition I have for whoever has those letters.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: dryly I'll tell him when he comes in.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: Rick, I'll put my cards on the table. I think you know where those letters are.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Well, you're in good company. Renault and Strasser probably think so, too.

scene.dir: Rick looks out of the window and sees Ilsa at the linen bazaar, then Laszlo walking toward the cafe.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: That's why I came over here to give them a chance to ransack my place.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: Rick, don't be a fool. Take me into your confidence. You need a partner.

scene.dir: Rick isn't listening to him. He looks through the open window in the direction of the linen bazaar. Rick gets up.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Excuse me, I'll be getting back.

scene.setting: EXT. THE BLUE PARROT - DAY Laszlo reaches the entrance to the cafe as Rick comes out. He stops and addresses Rick politely.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Good morning.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Signor Ferrari is the fat gent at the table.

scene.dir: As he exits, Laszlo looks after him with a puzzled expression.

scene.setting: EXT. BLACK MARKET - DAY At the linen stall, Ilsa examines a tablecloth which an Arab vendor is endeavoring to sell. He holds a sign which reads "700 francs."

sp.speaker: ARAB
sp.diag: You will not find a treasure like this in all Morocco, Mademoiselle. Only seven hundred francs.

scene.dir: Rick walks up behind Ilsa.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: You're being cheated.

scene.dir: She looks briefly at Rick, then turns away. Her manner is politely formal.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: It doesn't matter, thank you.

sp.speaker: ARAB
sp.diag: Ah, the lady is a friend of Rick's? For friends of Rick we have a small discount. Did I say seven hundred francs? You can have it for two hundred.

scene.dir: Reaching under the counter, he takes out a sign reading "200 francs", and replaces the other sign with it.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I'm sorry I was in no condition to receive you when you called on me last night.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: It doesn't matter.

sp.speaker: ARAB
sp.diag: Ah, for special friends of Rick's we have a special discount. One hundred francs.

scene.dir: He replaces the second sign with a third which reads "100 francs."

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Your story had me a little confused. Or maybe it was the bourbon.

sp.speaker: ARAB
sp.diag: I have some tablecloths, some napkins --

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: -- Thank you. I'm really not interested.

sp.speaker: ARAB
sp.diag: Please, one minute. Wait!

scene.dir: The Arab hurriedly exits. Ilsa pretends to examine the goods on the counter.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Why did you come back? To tell me why you ran out on me at the railway station?

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Yes.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Well, you can tell me now. I'm reasonably sober.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: I don't think I will, Rick.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Why not? After all, I got stuck with a railway ticket. I think I'm entitled to know.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Last night I saw what has happened to you. The Rick I knew in Paris, I could tell him. He'd understand. But the one who looked at me with such hatred-- well, I'll be leaving Casablanca soon and we'll never see each other again. We knew very little about each other when we were in love in Paris. If we leave it that way, maybe we'll remember those days and not Casablanca, not last night.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Did you run out on me because you couldn't take it? Because you knew what it would be like, hiding from the police, running away all the time?

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: You can believe that if you want to.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Well, I'm not running away any more. I'm settled now, above a saloon, it's true, but-- walk up a flight. I'll be expecting you.

scene.dir: Ilsa turns her head away.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: All the same, someday you'll lie to Laszlo. You'll be there.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: No, Rick. No, you see, Victor Laszlo is my husband-- and was, even when I knew you in Paris.

scene.dir: She walks away into the cafe as Rick stares after her in stunned disbelief.

scene.setting: INT. THE BLUE PARROT - DAY Ilsa and Laszlo sit with Ferrari.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: I was just telling Monsieur Laszlo that, unfortunately, I am not able to help him.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Oh.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: You see, my dear, the word has gone around.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: to Ilsa As leader of all illegal activities in Casablanca, I am an influential and respected man. It would not be worth my life to do anything for Monsieur Laszlo. You, however, are a different matter.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Signor Ferrari thinks it might just be possible to get an exit visa for you.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: You mean for me to go on alone?

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: And only alone.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: I will stay here and keep on trying. I'm sure in a little while --

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: -- We might as well be frank, Monsieur. It will take a miracle to get you out of Casablanca. And the Germans have outlawed miracles.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: We are only interested in two visas, Signor.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Please, Ilsa, don't be hasty.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: firmly No, Victor, no.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: You two will want to discuss this. Excuse me. I'll be at the bar.

scene.dir: Ferrari gets to his feet and walks away.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: No, Ilsa, I won't let you stay here. You must get to America. And believe me, somehow I will get out and join you.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: But, Victor, if the situation were different, if I had to stay and there were only a visa for one, would you take it?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: not very convincingly Yes, I would.

scene.dir: Ilsa smiles faintly. She doesn't believe it for even a moment.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Yes, I see. When I had trouble getting out of Lille, why didn't you leave me there? And when I was sick in Marseilles and held you up for two weeks and you were in danger every minute of the time, why didn't you leave me then?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: I meant to, but something always held me up. I love you very much, Ilsa.

scene.dir: She smiles again.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Your secret will be safe with me. Ferrari is waiting for our answer.

scene.dir: At the bar Ferrari talks to a waiter.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: Not more than fifty francs though.

scene.dir: Ilsa and Laszlo walk up to him.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: We've decided, Signor Ferrari. For the present we'll go on looking for two exit visas. Thank you very much.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: Well, good luck. But be careful. a flick of his eyes in the direction of the bazaar You know you're being shadowed?

scene.dir: Laszlo glances in the direction of the bazaar.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Of course. It becomes an instinct.

scene.dir: Ferrari looks shrewdly at Ilsa.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: I observe that you in one respect are a very fortunate man, Monsieur. I am moved to make one more suggestion, why, I do not know, because it cannot possibly profit me, but, have you heard about Signor Ugarte and the letters of transit?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Yes, something.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: Those letters were not found on Ugarte when they arrested him.

scene.dir: There's a moments pause as this sinks in.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Do you know where they are?

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: Not for sure, Monsieur, but I will venture to guess that Ugarte left those letters with Monsieur Rick.

scene.dir: Ilsa's face darkens. Laszlo quietly observes.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Rick?

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: He is a difficult customer, that Rick. One never knows what he'll do or why. But it is worth a chance.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Thank you very much. Good day.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Goodbye, thank you for your coffee, Signor. I shall miss that when we leave Casablanca.

scene.dir: Ferrari bows.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: It was gracious of you to share it with me. Good day, Mademoiselle, Monsieur.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Good day.

scene.dir: As Ilsa and Laszlo leave the cafe, Ferrari nonchalantly swats a fly on a table.

scene.setting: EXT. RICK'S CAFE - NIGHT Outside Rick's cafe, the sign is lit up and MUSIC filters out into the air.
INT. RICK'S CAFE - MAIN ROOM - NIGHT At the bar, the European has found another TOURIST.

sp.speaker: EUROPEAN
sp.diag: Here's to you, sir.

sp.speaker: TOURIST
sp.diag: Er, good luck, yes.

sp.speaker: EUROPEAN
sp.diag: I'd better be going.

sp.speaker: TOURIST
sp.diag: Er, my check, please.

sp.speaker: EUROPEAN
sp.diag: I have to warn you, sir. I beseech you--

scene.dir: The European picks his pocket.

sp.speaker: EUROPEAN
sp.diag: This is a dangerous place, full of vultures. Vultures everywhere! Thanks for everything.

scene.dir: The tourist laughs.

sp.speaker: TOURIST
sp.diag: Er, goodbye, sir.

sp.speaker: EUROPEAN
sp.diag: It has been a pleasure to meet you.

scene.dir: He dashes off and collides with Carl.

sp.speaker: EUROPEAN
sp.diag: Oh, I'm sorry.

scene.dir: As the European hurries away, Carl checks all his pockets to make sure nothing is missing. Sam and Corina play a number, accompanied by the orchestra. Strasser and his crowd enter the cafe and pass Rick's table. Carl brings Rick a bottle and glass.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: Monsieur Rick, you are getting to be your best customer.

scene.dir: Carl leaves. As Rick lights a cigarette, Renault shows up.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Well, Ricky. I'm very pleased with you. Now you're beginning to live like a Frenchman.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: That was some going-over your men gave my place this afternoon. We just barely got cleaned up in time to open.

scene.dir: He pours a drink for Renault.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Well, I told Strasser he wouldn't find the letters here. But I told my men to be especially destructive. You know how that impresses Germans? taking a sip Rick, have you got these letters of transit?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Louis, are you pro-Vichy or Free French?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Serves me right for asking a direct question. The subject is closed.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Well, it looks like you're a little late.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Huh?

scene.dir: Rick gazes at Yvonne and a GERMAN OFFICER approaching the bar.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: So Yvonne's gone over to the enemy.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Who knows? In her own way she may constitute an entire second front. I think it's time for me to flatter Major Strasser a little. I'll see you later, Rick.

scene.dir: Renault gets up and strolls away. At the bar, Yvonne and the German officer place their orders.

sp.speaker: YVONNE
sp.diag: Sacha!

sp.speaker: GERMAN OFFICER
sp.diag: French seventy-fives.

scene.dir: Yvonne is somewhat drunk already.

sp.speaker: YVONNE
sp.diag: Put up a whole row of them, Sacha-- starting here and ending here.

scene.dir: She indicates with her hand where she wants them.

sp.speaker: GERMAN OFFICER
sp.diag: We will begin with two.

scene.dir: A FRENCH OFFICER at the bar makes a remark to Yvonne.

sp.speaker: FRENCH OFFICER
sp.diag: in French Say, you, you are not French to go with a German like this!

sp.speaker: YVONNE
sp.diag: in French What are you butting in for?

sp.speaker: FRENCH OFFICER
sp.diag: in French I am butting in --

sp.speaker: YVONNE
sp.diag: breaking in, in French -- It's none of your business!

sp.speaker: GERMAN OFFICER
sp.diag: in French No, no, no, no! One minute! in English What did you say? Would you kindly repeat it?

sp.speaker: FRENCH OFFICER
sp.diag: What I said is none of your business!

sp.speaker: GERMAN OFFICER
sp.diag: I will make it my business! They begin to fight.

sp.speaker: YVONNE
sp.diag: in French Stop! I beg of you! I beg of you, stop!

scene.dir: There are exclamations from people nearby. German officers at a nearby table rise, ready to join in. Rick walks up and separates the two men.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: to the German I don't like disturbances in my place. Either lay off politics or get out.

sp.speaker: FRENCH OFFICER
sp.diag: in French Dirty Boche. Someday we'll have our revenge!

scene.dir: Renault, Strasser and the other officers sit down again.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: You see, Captain, the situation is not as much under control as you believe.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: My dear Major, we are trying to cooperate with your government, but we cannot regulate the feelings of our people.

scene.dir: Strasser eyes him closely.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Captain Renault, are you entirely certain which side you're on?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: I have no conviction, if that's what you mean. I blow with the wind, and the prevailing wind happens to be from Vichy.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: And if it should change?

scene.dir: He smiles.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Surely the Reich doesn't admit that possibility?

scene.dir: Renault lights a cigarette and puffs away.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: We are concerned about more than Casablanca. We know that every French province in Africa is honey-combed with traitors waiting for their chance, waiting, perhaps, for a leader.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: casually A leader, like Laszlo?

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Uh, huh. I have been thinking. It is too dangerous if we let him go. It may be too dangerous if we let him stay.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: thoughtfully I see what you mean. Carl, bottle in hand, approaches the table of a middle-aged German couple, the LEUCHTAGS.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: in German I brought you the finest brandy. Only the employees drink it here.

scene.dir: He pours a drink for each of them.

sp.speaker: MR. LEUCHTAG
sp.diag: Thank you, Carl.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: as he pours For Mrs. Leuchtag.

sp.speaker: MRS. LEUCHTAG
sp.diag: Thank you, Carl.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: For Mr. Leuchtag.

sp.speaker: MR. LEUCHTAG
sp.diag: Carl, sit down. Have a brandy with us. MRS. LEUCHTAG beaming with happiness To celebrate our leaving for America tomorrow. Carl sits down.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: Thank you very much. I thought you would ask me, so I brought the good brandy and a third glass.

scene.dir: He produces a glass from a back pocket.

sp.speaker: MRS. LEUCHTAG
sp.diag: At last the day has come.

sp.speaker: MR. LEUCHTAG
sp.diag: Frau Leuchtag and I are speaking nothing but English now.

sp.speaker: MRS. LEUCHTAG
sp.diag: So we should feel at home ven ve get to America.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: A very nice idea.

sp.speaker: MR. LEUCHTAG
sp.diag: To America.

scene.dir: Mrs. Leuchtag and Carl repeat "To America." They clink glasses and drink.

sp.speaker: MR. LEUCHTAG
sp.diag: Liebchen, uh, sweetness heart, what watch?

scene.dir: She glances at her wristwatch.

sp.speaker: MRS. LEUCHTAG
sp.diag: Ten watch.

sp.speaker: MR. LEUCHTAG
sp.diag: Such much?

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: Er, you will get along beautifully in America, huh.

scene.dir: Annina meets Renault in the hallway as she leaves the gambling room,

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: How's lady luck treating you? Aw, too bad. You'll find him over there.

scene.dir: Annina sees Rick and goes to his table.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Monsieur Rick?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Yes?

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Could I speak to you for just a moment, please?

scene.dir: Rick looks at her.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: How did you get in here? You're under age.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: I came with Captain Renault.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: cynically I should have known.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: My husband is with me, too.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: He is? Well, Captain Renault's getting broadminded. Sit down. Will you have a drink?

scene.dir: Annina shakes her head.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: No, of course not. Do you mind if I do?

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: No.

scene.dir: Rick pours himself a drink

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Monsieur Rick, what kind of man is Captain Renault?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Oh, he's just like any other man, only more so.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: No, I mean, is he trustworthy? Is his word --

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: -- Now, just a minute. Who told you to ask me that?

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: He did. Captain Renault did.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I thought so. Where's your husband?

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: At the roulette table, trying to win enough for our exit visa. Well of course, he's losing.

scene.dir: Rick looks at her closely.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: How long have you been married?

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Eight weeks. We come from Bulgaria. Oh, things are very bad there, Monsieur. A devil has the people by the throat. So, Jan and I, we, we do not want our children to grow up in such a country.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: wearily So you decided to go to America.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Yes, but we have not much money, and travelling is so expensive and difficult. It was much more than we thought to get here. And then Captain Renault sees us and he is so kind. He wants to help us.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Yes, I'll bet.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: He tells me he can give us an exit visa, but we have no money.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Does he know that?

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Oh, yes.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: And he is still willing to give you a visa?

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Yes, Monsieur.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: And you want to know --

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: -- Will he keep his word?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: He always has.

scene.dir: There is a silence. Annina is very disturbed.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Oh, Monsieur, you are a man. If someone loved you very much, so that your happiness was the only thing that she wanted in the whole world, but she did a bad thing to make certain of it, could you forgive her?

scene.dir: Rick stares off into space.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Nobody ever loved me that much.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: And he never knew, and the girl kept this bad thing locked in her heart? That would be all right, wouldn't it?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: harshly You want my advice?

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Oh, yes, please.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Go back to Bulgaria.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Oh, but if you knew what it means to us to leave Europe, to get to America! Oh, but if Jan should find out! He is such a boy. In many ways I am so much older than he is.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Yes, well, everybody in Casablanca has problems. Yours may work out. You'll excuse me.

scene.dir: Rick abruptly rises.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: tonelessly Thank you, Monsieur.

scene.dir: He quickly goes off, leaving Annina alone at the table. She remains seated, too demoralized to move. While Rick checks the reservation list, Ilsa and Laszlo enter the cafe. In the background we hear Sam playing, ironically enough, "It Had to Be You." Rick greets Ilsa and Laszlo.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Good evening.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Good evening. You see, here we are again.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I take that as a great compliment to Sam. to Ilsa I suppose he means to you Paris of, well, happier days.

scene.dir: Laszlo looks around.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: quietly He does. Could we have a table close to him?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: And as far away from Major Strasser as possible.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Well, the geography may be a little difficult to arrange.

scene.dir: Rick snaps his fingers for the headwaiter.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Paul! Table thirty!

sp.speaker: HEADWAITER
sp.diag: to Ilsa and Laszlo Yes, sir. Right this way, if you please.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: to Ilsa I'll have Sam play "As Time Goes By." I believe that's your favorite tune.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: smiling Thank you.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Two cognacs, please.

scene.dir: Rick walks over to Sam and whispers something to him. Sam stops what he is playing and begins "As Time Goes By." He shakes his head as Rick leaves. A waiter appears at Ilsa and Laszlo's table.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - GAMBLING ROOM - NIGHT Jan sits at the roulette table. He has only three chips left and seems bewildered. As Rick comes up the croupier speaks to Jan.

sp.speaker: CROUPIER
sp.diag: Do you wish to place another bet, sir?

sp.speaker: JAN
sp.diag: No, no, I guess not.

scene.dir: Rick stands behind Jan.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: to Jan Have you tried twenty-two tonight? I said, twenty-two.

scene.dir: Jan looks at Rick, then at the chips in his hand. He pauses, then puts the chips on twenty-two. Rick and the croupier exchange looks. The croupier understands what Rick wants him to do. He spins the wheel. Carl follows the proceedings, fascinated. The wheel stops spinning.

sp.speaker: CROUPIER
sp.diag: in French Twenty-two, black, twenty-two. A winner. Renault, at a nearby table, takes notice of what is happening. The croupier pushes a pile of chips onto twenty-two and Jan reaches for it.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: not even looking at Jan Leave it there. Jan hesitates, then withdraws his hands. Carl continues to watch. The wheel spins. Nobody speaks while it spins. It stops.

sp.speaker: CROUPIER
sp.diag: Twenty-two, black. Another winner. The croupier shoves a pile of chips toward Jan.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: to Jan Cash it in and don't come back.

scene.dir: Jan rises to go to the cashier. A CUSTOMER complains to Carl.

sp.speaker: CUSTOMER
sp.diag: Say, are you sure this place is honest?

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: fervently Honest! As honest as the day is long!

scene.dir: Meanwhile, Rick has walked over to the croupier.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: How we doing tonight?

sp.speaker: CROUPIER
sp.diag: Well, a couple of thousand less than I thought there would be.

scene.dir: Rick smiles slightly and goes toward the door. Annina runs up to him and hugs him.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Monsieur Rick, I --

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: -- He's just a lucky guy.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: solicitously Monsieur Rick, may I get you a cup of coffee?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: No thanks, Carl.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: Monsieur Rick!

scene.dir: Renault, seeing that Jan has won, gets up from his table to follow Rick. Jan and Annina stop him on the way.

sp.speaker: JAN
sp.diag: Captain Renault, may I --

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: -- Oh, not here, please. Come to my office in the morning. We'll do everything business-like.

sp.speaker: JAN
sp.diag: We'll be there at six.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: I'll be there at ten. I am very happy for both of you. Still, it's very strange that you won.

scene.dir: He looks over and sees Rick.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Well, maybe not so strange. I'll see you in the morning.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Thank you so much, Captain Renault.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - MAIN ROOM - NIGHT At the bar, Carl whispers in Sacha's ear. Sacha says "No!" and runs to Rick.

sp.speaker: SACHA
sp.diag: Boss, you've done a beautiful thing.

scene.dir: He kisses Rick on both cheeks.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Go away, you crazy Russian!

scene.dir: Carl pours a brandy for Rick. Pretending not to do so, Rick glances in Ilsa's direction. Renault comes up to him.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: As I suspected, you're a rank sentimentalist.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Yeah? Why?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: chidingly Why do you interfere with my little romances?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Put it down as a gesture to love.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: good-naturedly Well, I forgive you this time. But I'll be in tomorrow night with a breathtaking blonde, and it will make me very happy if she loses. Uh huh!

scene.dir: He smiles and walks away. Laszlo comes up to Rick.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Monsieur Blaine, I wonder if I could talk to you?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Go ahead.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Well, isn't there some other place? It's rather confidential, what I have to say.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: My office.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Right.
